objinfo.objsize: full sheet 22.8 x 36.4 cm.Unfolded full sheet and Leaf Size dimensions (height x width) are given according to the vertical orientation of the body of Cumberland's letter; see the note on Number of Leaves, below. Object 1 has been reoriented vertically in the Object View Page, as would be customary when reading the page.
objinfo.numberleaves: 2The full sheet was folded to form two leaves. Cumberland's letter appears on the first recto (Object 1), first verso (Object 2), and second recto (Object 3) of the folded sheet. The second verso is not pictured. Below the end of Cumberland's letter to Blake on Object 3, Cumberland added instructions to his son, also named George, to deliver the letter and await Blake's response in person. Blake responded to Cumberland the following day in a separate letter dated 19 December 1808 that is available through the Index of Letters. The full sheet view of Objects 2 and 3 is available as a Supplemental View on the Object View Page for those objects.

provenance.name: British Library
provenance.note: George Cumberland; bequeathed to his son, George Cumberland; presented to the British Library in 1849, as part of the Cumberland Papers consisting of thirty-one volumes and two rolls, on condition that these should not be opened until 1900.

desc.objtitle: A gentleman of my acquaintance Letter from George Cumberland, 18 December 1808, Object 1

objnote.p: The full sheet was folded to form two leaves. Cumberland's letter appears on the first recto (Object 1), first verso (Object 2), and second recto (Object 3) of the folded sheet. The second verso is not pictured. Below the end of Cumberland's letter to Blake on Object 3, Cumberland added instructions to his son, also named George, to deliver the letter and await Blake's response in person. Blake responded to Cumberland the following day in a separate letter dated 19 December 1808 that is available through the Index of Letters. The full sheet view of objects 2 and 3 is available as a Supplemental View on the Object View Page for those objects.

In the upper left corner an illegible stamp is visible. Along the upper right edge, Cumberland has inscribed to his son, "Your Line dr George is at the end of the Sheet", around which a line division is drawn. Bentley (Writings volume 2, page 1642) reads "Sheet" as "Street" in this inscription. Below Cumberland's inscription, "3/2" is inscribed in a darker ink in an unknown hand.

lg.l: Dear Blake,
A gentleman of my acquaintance to
whom I was shewingshowing your incomparable etchings
last night was so charmed with them, that
he requested me to get him a compleatcomplete SetKeynes (Letters, page 136) reads "Set" as "set".
of all you have published in the way of Books
colored Coloured as mine are; _ and at the same timeKeynes (Letters, page 136) reads "Coloured" as “colour’d”.
he wishes to know what will be the price
of as many as you can spare him, if all are
not to be had, being willing to wait your own
time in order to have them as those of mine are.
With respect to the money I will takeKeynes (Letters, page 136) reads "money" as "Money".
care that it shall be reced and sent to you
through my Son as fast as they are procured.
I find by a Letter from my son
that the picture you sent, he asked you for,

objnote.p: The full sheet was folded to form two leaves. Cumberland's letter appears on the first recto (Object 1), first verso (Object 2), and second recto (Object 3) of the folded sheet. The second verso is not pictured. Below the end of Cumberland's letter to Blake on Object 3, Cumberland added instructions to his son, also named George, to deliver the letter and await Blake's response in person. Blake responded to Cumberland the following day in a separate letter dated 19 December 1808 that is available through the Index of Letters. The full sheet view of Objects 2 and 3 is available as a Supplemental View on the Object View Page for those objects.

lg.l: which is what I do not approve, as I
certainly had no such thing in contemplation
when I sent you those very slight sketches
from RaffaelRaphael, _ I Am glad however thatKeynes (*Letters*, page 136) reads "Am" as "am".
you found them acceptable, and shall certainly
send you a few more as soon as I can light

on them among my papers. _ The Holy family isBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1642n4) notes that "Blake's 'Holy Family' has not been traced." This work, probably a tempera painting, is number 672 in Butlin's catalogue, where he also lists it as “Untraced since 1808”.
like all your designs full of Genius and
originality. I shall give it a handsome frame
and shewshow it to all who come to my house.
—When you answer this pray tell me
if you have been able to do anything with theBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1642) reads "anything" as "any thing".
Bookseller._ something of that kind would be
no bad thing, and might turn out a great one
if a competition could be raised by that meansBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1643) reads "by that" as "by this".

among the genuine qymeliars of talents of every Keynes (*Letters*, page 137n1) suggests "qymeliars" for the uncertain term Blake uses in this line, which he explains as "A doubtful word, probably intended for 'cymeliarchs' from *κειμηλιαρχος*, a treasurer, or storekeeper, as suggested by the late W. E. Moss.". Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1643) reads "qymeliars" as "appre[cia]ters".
sort __ You talked also of publishing

objnote.p: The full sheet was folded to form two leaves. Cumberland's letter appears on the first recto (Object 1), first verso (Object 2), and second recto (Object 3) of the folded sheet. The second verso is not pictured. Below the end of Cumberland's letter to Blake on Object 3, Cumberland added instructions to his son, also named George, to deliver the letter and await Blake's response in person. Blake responded to Cumberland the following day in a separate letter dated 19 December 1808 that is available through the Index of Letters. The full sheet view of Objects 2 and 3 is available as a Supplemental View on the Object View Page for those objects.

In the upper right corner "3/3" is inscribed in ink in an unknown hand. Below Cumberland's signature, a line division is inscribed above Cumberland's instructions to his son, also named George. The instructions read "Dear George. / [deleted; "Take the above to Mr Blake, and"] Go on receit of this to Black Friars & when You / have been to Sr. R Phillips to know if he got my / 24 Pages of Biography sent by Fromonts Coach carriage / Paid & booked on Wednesday last — take the above to Mr Blake / and get him to answer it directly on the Sheet of Paper on / which you write your answer as to the receit of the Biography of / Grignion—but say nothing to his Brother as to where I publish it as / yet. I shall ret.n his Papers. All well & all desire love [illegible characters] / PS. If you have my Lett. through S. R Phillips, it is come safe |Yours. GC.

lg.l: your new method of engraving _ send it to me
and I will do my best to prepare it for the
Press._ perhaps when done you might with a
few specimens of Plates make a like workBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1642) reads “like” as “little”.

for subscribers of it _ as Du Crow did of hisKeynes (*Letters*, page 137) reads "of it" as "for it". Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1643) notes that "Du Crow" is "probably Pierre Ducros (1745-1810), popular painter and engraver of landscapes."
Aqua-tinta _ selling about 6 Pages for half a
guinea to non subscribers _ but if you do not
chusechoose that method; we might insert it in NicholsonsNicholson'sWilliam NicholsonBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1642) reads "that method" as "this method".
Journal or the Monthly Magazine.- with reference to
you for explanations _ with best regards to
you & yoursI am always
your sincere friend

CulvCulvert Street
e rtSt 18 DecDecember. 1808 _G.CumberlandGeorge Cumberland. Keynes (*Letters*, page 211) reads "CulvertSt" as "Culworth". George Cumberland lived at Culvert Street, Bristol, so "Culworth" appears a misreading. Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1643) reads "Culvert St".
Below Cumberland's signature and a line division, Cumberland inscribes further instructions to his son, also named George, about the delivery of the letter. These instructions are transcribed in the Object Note.
